summary: I'm totally fine with Jon not being the one to kill the night king. I'm even fine with arya being the one to give the final...
question: I'm totally fine with Jon not being the one to kill the night king. I'm even fine with arya being the one to give the final blow. I just wish it was more of a team effort between Arya and Bran. I always thought that the first scene in ep 1 with bran missing every shot and arya hitting the bullseye was foreshadowing something important. Especially since he had a few visions holding a bow and arrow, I always thought that it would come full circle but instead he just sat there.
answer: Oh yeah same they definitely dropped the ball with Bran lol no doubt about that. I’m really disappointed with his character because honestly I expected him to be the one to stop the Night King in the end and they really just didn’t do anything with his character. My original theory for the Night Kings ending was that Jamie and Bran would tag team the NK. The episode definitely had its issues and plot holes, but I went into this season with very low expectations for everyone especially Arya and to see that episode was amazing. I just have to separate the books and the show because I think the books are going to focus more on fufilling the prophecies and giving Bran a bigger arc. The show obviously needed to wrap up the NK and Brans story quick so they went with this and if I don’t think too hard about I’m happy with the episode overall.

summary: Okay rewatching the episode. Upon reflection and in my baby’s defence, Jon actually did try to fight the NK in one on one...
body: Okay rewatching the episode. Upon reflection and in my baby’s defence, Jon actually did try to fight the NK in one on one combat, but the NK knows who would best who and so said nah I’m gud luv, enjoy. The reason Jon isn’t with Bran in the first place is because Daenerys and her impulsive self decided “the dead are already here.” & flew off on Drogon. Okay. Also, I think when Jon is screaming at Viserion (which was quite comical I won’t lie), he probably thought he was going to die and was about to charge at Viserion.

summary: let me make something very, very clear, everything that happened last night, happened because of jon. the unsullied and the...
body: let me make something very, very clear, everything that happened last night, happened because of jon. the unsullied and the dothraki saved the northern army and allowed them to reteat because jon got them there, daenerys and drogon attacked viserion and dethroned the night king because jon brought them there, the wildlings fought for the north because jon united them, jaime was there because jon convinced him of their existance, arya killed the night king because jon prepared her for the threat, the northern lords were there because jon (and sansa) united them again, daenerys and her dragon’s were there because jon convinced them of the threat, the hound and beric were there to save arya because they were loyal to jon, lyanna killed the giant because jon convinced her to help them, every single person that had dragon glass had it because jon got it for them and gendry was there to forge it because jon recruited him. without jon, winterfell, the north, and the rest of westeros would be dead. so i don’t want to hear one more word about jon “not doing anything.”

summary: Prompt: Jon introducing gendry to arya ;) thank you!
question: Prompt: Jon introducing gendry to arya ;) thank you!
answer:
“How much can we reuse?”

Gendry matches Jon’s fast pace as they cross Winterfell’s courtyard to the battlements. He hasn’t slept in about thirty hours and he imagines it’s been longer for the King in the North. The air is thick with smoke and rot, and it’s made almost everyone’s eyes red-rimmed.

He shakes his head. “Not the steel or the dragonglass that’s going to be the problem.” He pauses long enough to eye the pyre they’re constructing for the mass funeral later. “It’s the amount of hands we have to hold them.”

Jon’s face always looks grim, but there’s a distance to his gaze now that Gendry doesn’t like. Perhaps for the first time, he’s glad to be low-born. The low-born don’t make the decisions that end up getting everyone killed.

“See what you can do for arrows and spears, then.”

“‘Course.”

They climb the steps to what’s left of the wall. And Gendry is so deep in thought that he misses the rare smile that crosses Jon’s face when they reach the top.

“Arya,” he greets, and Gendry’s head snaps up.

She’s standing next to her sister, the bloody Lady of Winterfell, and their conversation falls away as Jon approaches them. Hesitantly, Gendry follows suit, rubbing the back of his neck and wondering how this is all going to go.

Arya’s smile is for Jon, he’s not stupid enough to think otherwise, but when her eyes meet his it turns into something more like a smirk. That makes him stupid.

“Jon,” the Lady of Winterfell greets, her eyes flickering to him. “And Ser…?”

“Just Gendry.”

Jon claps him on the shoulder, addressing his sisters. “He’s the smith responsible for all the weapons. We met at the Wall.”

Arya folds her hands behind her back, staring expectantly, and Gendry just knows she’s going to watch him make a complete ass of himself and be happy about it.

“Winterfell thanks you,” the Lady says kindly. And then Gendry feels his stomach tie into knots as she sends him a slow look that transfers to Arya. Her eyebrow quirks, just a little, and she bows her head. “I’m afraid I’m needed elsewhere.”

The Lady makes her exit, and then it’s just the three of them. Gendry looks anywhere but at the Starks, not sure what he’s supposed to be saying.

“He’s the son of Robert Baratheon,” Jon continues.

Arya tilts her head. “You don’t say.”

Jon clears his throat, as if just realizing he’s forgotten something. “My sister, Arya.”

Gendry is sure his face is bright red now. “M’lady.”

And she is definitely fighting a smile. “My Lord.”

“Not a lord.”

“And you know I’m not a lady.”

Jon’s brows draw as he looks between them. “Something the matter?”

“We’ve met,” Arya says calmly.

And Gendry thinks that this is his death, finally coming for him. “I worked with her on a staff.”

“That’s not all we worked on.”

He’s a dead man. Completely dead. He glares at Arya, who only grins.

Jon’s frown increases. He looks like a man trying to untangle a knot. “So you’re friends?”

“Good friends,” Gendry says at the same time Arya goes, “Not really.”

Your brother’s going to murder me, he tries to communicate with his widened eyes and slightly parted mouth.

Try harder not to be murdered, the cool rise of her eyebrows suggests.

The standstill feels like it lasts forever, until it’s broken by The Hound stomping past them, a hunk of debris from the wall in his hands.

“She’s fucking the twat,” he states with annoyance, shoving both Jon and Gendry apart as he makes to move past them. “You daft bloody bastard.”

The Hound leaves. Gendry’s body goes numb. Arya snorts. Jon can’t seem to move.

“You’re…what?” Jon finally manages.

Arya shrugs, turning around and walking in the same direction as The Hound.

Gendry is incapacitated. Does he run? He should run. He’s been abandoned. She abandoned him.

Jon clears his throat. The silence stretches. He should fucking run. Back to Flea Bottom, maybe. Or Essos. An island somewhere. He can row now.

“So,” Jon manages, face still in that expression of undoing a knot.

Gendry wonders if he’d survive jumping off the battlements.

“The arrows,” Jon finally settles on, looking very pale.

“Arrows.” Gendry intones. “Right. Arrows.”

“Right.”

“Go…make some.”

“Right.”

Jon shakes his head, clearly unable to process what he’s just heard, and then the King of the North walks away much faster than he was walking before.

Gendry can’t help the small, strangled laugh that escapes him as he looks up at the sky.

“Fuck.”

Gendry matches Jon’s fast pace as they cross Winterfell’s courtyard to the battlements. He hasn’t slept in about thirty hours and he imagines it’s been longer for the King in the North. The air is thick with smoke and rot, and it’s made almost everyone’s eyes red-rimmed.

He shakes his head. “Not the steel or the dragonglass that’s going to be the problem.” He pauses long enough to eye the pyre they’re constructing for the mass funeral later. “It’s the amount of hands we have to hold them.”

Jon’s face always looks grim, but there’s a distance to his gaze now that Gendry doesn’t like. Perhaps for the first time, he’s glad to be low-born. The low-born don’t make the decisions that end up getting everyone killed.

“See what you can do for arrows and spears, then.”

“‘Course.”

They climb the steps to what’s left of the wall. And Gendry is so deep in thought that he misses the rare smile that crosses Jon’s face when they reach the top.

“Arya,” he greets, and Gendry’s head snaps up.

She’s standing next to her sister, the bloody Lady of Winterfell, and their conversation falls away as Jon approaches them. Hesitantly, Gendry follows suit, rubbing the back of his neck and wondering how this is all going to go.

Arya’s smile is for Jon, he’s not stupid enough to think otherwise, but when her eyes meet his it turns into something more like a smirk. That makes him stupid.

“Jon,” the Lady of Winterfell greets, her eyes flickering to him. “And Ser…?”

“Just Gendry.”

Jon claps him on the shoulder, addressing his sisters. “He’s the smith responsible for all the weapons. We met at the Wall.”

Arya folds her hands behind her back, staring expectantly, and Gendry just knows she’s going to watch him make a complete ass of himself and be happy about it.

“Winterfell thanks you,” the Lady says kindly. And then Gendry feels his stomach tie into knots as she sends him a slow look that transfers to Arya. Her eyebrow quirks, just a little, and she bows her head. “I’m afraid I’m needed elsewhere.”

The Lady makes her exit, and then it’s just the three of them. Gendry looks anywhere but at the Starks, not sure what he’s supposed to be saying.

“He’s the son of Robert Baratheon,” Jon continues.

Arya tilts her head. “You don’t say.”

Jon clears his throat, as if just realizing he’s forgotten something. “My sister, Arya.”

Gendry is sure his face is bright red now. “M’lady.”

And she is definitely fighting a smile. “My Lord.”

“Not a lord.”

“And you know I’m not a lady.”

Jon’s brows draw as he looks between them. “Something the matter?”

“We’ve met,” Arya says calmly.

And Gendry thinks that this is his death, finally coming for him. “I worked with her on a staff.”

“That’s not all we worked on.”

He’s a dead man. Completely dead. He glares at Arya, who only grins.

Jon’s frown increases. He looks like a man trying to untangle a knot. “So you’re friends?”

“Good friends,” Gendry says at the same time Arya goes, “Not really.”

Your brother’s going to murder me, he tries to communicate with his widened eyes and slightly parted mouth.

Try harder not to be murdered, the cool rise of her eyebrows suggests.

The standstill feels like it lasts forever, until it’s broken by The Hound stomping past them, a hunk of debris from the wall in his hands.

“She’s fucking the twat,” he states with annoyance, shoving both Jon and Gendry apart as he makes to move past them. “You daft bloody bastard.”

The Hound leaves. Gendry’s body goes numb. Arya snorts. Jon can’t seem to move.

“You’re…what?” Jon finally manages.

Arya shrugs, turning around and walking in the same direction as The Hound.

Gendry is incapacitated. Does he run? He should run. He’s been abandoned. She abandoned him.

Jon clears his throat. The silence stretches. He should fucking run. Back to Flea Bottom, maybe. Or Essos. An island somewhere. He can row now.

“So,” Jon manages, face still in that expression of undoing a knot.

Gendry wonders if he’d survive jumping off the battlements.

“The arrows,” Jon finally settles on, looking very pale.

“Arrows.” Gendry intones. “Right. Arrows.”

“Right.”

“Go…make some.”

“Right.”

Jon shakes his head, clearly unable to process what he’s just heard, and then the King of the North walks away much faster than he was walking before.

Gendry can’t help the small, strangled laugh that escapes him as he looks up at the sky.

“Fuck.”
trail.content:
“How much can we reuse?”

Gendry matches Jon’s fast pace as they cross Winterfell’s courtyard to the battlements. He hasn’t slept in about thirty hours and he imagines it’s been longer for the King in the North. The air is thick with smoke and rot, and it’s made almost everyone’s eyes red-rimmed.

He shakes his head. “Not the steel or the dragonglass that’s going to be the problem.” He pauses long enough to eye the pyre they’re constructing for the mass funeral later. “It’s the amount of hands we have to hold them.”

Jon’s face always looks grim, but there’s a distance to his gaze now that Gendry doesn’t like. Perhaps for the first time, he’s glad to be low-born. The low-born don’t make the decisions that end up getting everyone killed.

“See what you can do for arrows and spears, then.”

“‘Course.”

They climb the steps to what’s left of the wall. And Gendry is so deep in thought that he misses the rare smile that crosses Jon’s face when they reach the top.

“Arya,” he greets, and Gendry’s head snaps up.

She’s standing next to her sister, the bloody Lady of Winterfell, and their conversation falls away as Jon approaches them. Hesitantly, Gendry follows suit, rubbing the back of his neck and wondering how this is all going to go.

Arya’s smile is for Jon, he’s not stupid enough to think otherwise, but when her eyes meet his it turns into something more like a smirk. That makes him stupid.

“Jon,” the Lady of Winterfell greets, her eyes flickering to him. “And Ser…?”

“Just Gendry.”

Jon claps him on the shoulder, addressing his sisters. “He’s the smith responsible for all the weapons. We met at the Wall.”

Arya folds her hands behind her back, staring expectantly, and Gendry just knows she’s going to watch him make a complete ass of himself and be happy about it.

“Winterfell thanks you,” the Lady says kindly. And then Gendry feels his stomach tie into knots as she sends him a slow look that transfers to Arya. Her eyebrow quirks, just a little, and she bows her head. “I’m afraid I’m needed elsewhere.”

The Lady makes her exit, and then it’s just the three of them. Gendry looks anywhere but at the Starks, not sure what he’s supposed to be saying.

“He’s the son of Robert Baratheon,” Jon continues.

Arya tilts her head. “You don’t say.”

Jon clears his throat, as if just realizing he’s forgotten something. “My sister, Arya.”

Gendry is sure his face is bright red now. “M’lady.”

And she is definitely fighting a smile. “My Lord.”

“Not a lord.”

“And you know I’m not a lady.”

Jon’s brows draw as he looks between them. “Something the matter?”

“We’ve met,” Arya says calmly.

And Gendry thinks that this is his death, finally coming for him. “I worked with her on a staff.”

“That’s not all we worked on.”

He’s a dead man. Completely dead. He glares at Arya, who only grins.

Jon’s frown increases. He looks like a man trying to untangle a knot. “So you’re friends?”

“Good friends,” Gendry says at the same time Arya goes, “Not really.”

Your brother’s going to murder me, he tries to communicate with his widened eyes and slightly parted mouth.

Try harder not to be murdered, the cool rise of her eyebrows suggests.

The standstill feels like it lasts forever, until it’s broken by The Hound stomping past them, a hunk of debris from the wall in his hands.

“She’s fucking the twat,” he states with annoyance, shoving both Jon and Gendry apart as he makes to move past them. “You daft bloody bastard.”

The Hound leaves. Gendry’s body goes numb. Arya snorts. Jon can’t seem to move.

“You’re…what?” Jon finally manages.

Arya shrugs, turning around and walking in the same direction as The Hound.

Gendry is incapacitated. Does he run? He should run. He’s been abandoned. She abandoned him.

Jon clears his throat. The silence stretches. He should fucking run. Back to Flea Bottom, maybe. Or Essos. An island somewhere. He can row now.

“So,” Jon manages, face still in that expression of undoing a knot.

Gendry wonders if he’d survive jumping off the battlements.

“The arrows,” Jon finally settles on, looking very pale.

“Arrows.” Gendry intones. “Right. Arrows.”

“Right.”

“Go…make some.”

“Right.”

Jon shakes his head, clearly unable to process what he’s just heard, and then the King of the North walks away much faster than he was walking before.

Gendry can’t help the small, strangled laugh that escapes him as he looks up at the sky.

“Fuck.”

blog.description: Prompts are open! If you'd like to buy me a coffee, my Ko-Fi is at                ko-fi.com/avairvin.   Header artwork done by @wolvesofspring

tags: a song of ice and fire
summary: 8.03 meta
body:
8.03 meta

Maybe Azor Ahai (tptwp) was really just a way of gathering those who need to fight together. We don’t know if the story is true, (a single man fighting an army) could be as true as Roman/Greek legends.

So maybe, just maybe the song of ice and fire (JS) was meant to mediate an army large enough to fight. Simply hearing one side of each wasn’t enough. The northerners hatred of foreigners denied them help (Song of fire aka Dany)- until JON proved otherwise. and those who refused to believe in the NK was a blindfold meant to ensnare the rest to be slaughtered (a song of ice, NK)- until JON proved otherwise! (Ex: Dany/Jaime). You need balance. Jon is the inbwtween. He was born to bring these people together. You need a song people can listen to. And his is the song of ice and fire.

I believe Jon IS the ptwp. And his army, those he assembled, was his lightbringer. So many used fire to fight back, and it was just enough to win- and Arya, she was the blade. I’m not saying she isn’t special, but it certainly felt unearned and I think perhaps the title is even shared if that’s the case.

tags: a song of ice and fire
summary: Game of Thrones: The Long Night Review
title: Game of Thrones: The Long Night Review
description:
“Valar morghulis.”
“Valar dohaeris.”

We have been waiting for this confrontation from the first scene of the first episode. After nearly seventy minutes of overwhelming battle, we finally have an outcome to the biggest threat in Westeros.
